DeviceUserAgentHeader.description:
Used to improve end-user's authentication experience based on device type.
If omitted, the `User-Agent` header will be used instead.
DeviceUserAgentHeader.name: X-Device-User-Agent

IdempotencyKeyHeader.description:
An idempotency key to allow safe retrying without the operation being performed multiple times.
The value should be unique for each operation, e.g. a UUID, with the same key being sent on a retry of the same request.
IdempotencyKeyHeader.name: Idempotency-Key

OptionalIdempotencyKeyHeader.description:
An idempotency key to allow safe retrying without the operation being performed multiple times.
The value should be unique for each operation (we strongly advise to use a UUID v4), with the same key being sent on a retry of the same request.
OptionalIdempotencyKeyHeader.name: Idempotency-Key

OptionalIdempotencyKeyHeaderNoAuth.description:
An idempotency key to allow safe retrying without the operation being performed multiple times.
The value should be unique for each operation (we strongly advise to use a UUID v4), with the same key being sent on a retry of the same request.
If a UUID can't be used, we advise to also include your client id in the idempotency key.
OptionalIdempotencyKeyHeaderNoAuth.name: Idempotency-Key

PsuIpAddressHeader.description:
Used to collect and record end-user IP address.
The first IP address in the [list](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/X-Forwarded-For) will be used as the end-user IP address.
PsuIpAddressHeader.name: X-Forwarded-For

SignatureHeader.description:
A JWS with detached content, signed with your private key.
See [Request Signing](https://docs.truelayer.com/docs/sign-your-requests)
SignatureHeader.name: Tl-Signature

SignatureHeaderConditional.description:
A JWS with detached content, signed with your private key.
See [Request Signing](https://docs.truelayer.com/docs/sign-your-requests).

Required with a OAuth2 token.
SignatureHeaderConditional.name: Tl-Signature

WebhookSignatureHeader.description:
A JWS with detached content, verifiable with our public key.
See [Webhook Request Signing](/docs/configure-webhooks-for-your-integration#validate-the-signature-of-received-webhooks)
WebhookSignatureHeader.name: Tl-Signature

iban.description: Valid International Bank Account Number (no spaces). Consists of a 2 letter country code, followed by 2 check digits, and then by up to 30 alphanumeric characters (also known as the BBAN). pattern: `^[A-Z]{2}[0-9]{2}[A-Z0-9]{11,30}$`

OutboundPaymentFailureReason.description:
The reason the outbound payment failed.
Example values to expect:
- `insufficient_funds`
- `scheme_error`
- `server_error`
- `blocked`
- `returned`
- `account_not_valid`: the bank account(s) associated to the given AIS consent is/are not valid. Note that this error is only relevant for `user_determined` beneficiaries.
- `verification_name_mismatch`: the name provided as part of a payout verification does not match the one available on the connected bank account
- `verification_transaction_not_found`: the transaction details provided as part of a payout verification are not found within the associated bank account's transactions

Clients should handle unexpected values gracefully as a unknown failure.

consent.description:
Can your UI capture the user's consent?

This parameter states whether your UI can explicitly capture and report the end user's consent for initiating the payment.

If you omit this, the API may restrict the available providers if explicit consent is required.

action_type.description:
How you will capture consent as part of the authorisation flow:
- `explicit` (default): The authorisation flow returns an explicit `consent` action for you to respond to at an appropriate moment in the flow.
- `adjacent`: You provide the consent information alongside other actions in the flow. This enables the UI to combine capturing consent alongside with other actions, if you indicate consent is gathered when you respond to those actions. Note this is currently only supported on `form` actions.

form.description:
Can your UI render form inputs for the user to interact with?

Some providers require additional inputs, such as the remitter name and account details, to be provided before or during payment authorization. To facilitate this, the API may return a `form` action as part of the authorization flow, which means your UI must be able to collect the required inputs.

This parameter states whether your UI supports the `form` action. If you omit this parameter, the API returns only providers that don't require additional inputs. 

If the provider has been preselected and requires additional inputs, this field is required.

input_types.description: The types of input that your UI can render a form to collect.

provider_selection.description:
Can your UI render a provider selection screen?

In payments where you set `provider_selection` as `user_selected`, your UI must be able to render a screen where the user can select their payments provider. Use the `provider_selection.filter` parameter to determine which providers display in your UI.

This parameter is required for payments with `user_selected` provider selection. For `preselected` provider selection, it's optional.

redirect.description:
Can your UI redirect the user to a third-party page?

For most providers, the user authorises the payment after they're redirected to their chosen provider's page. There, they can sign in with their credentials and approve the payment. This parameter states whether your UI can handle such a redirect.

direct_return_uri.description:
Only applicable if you're regulated and have a direct return URI registered with UK providers.

If you're regulated, you can specify a `direct_return_uri` to attempt the authorization flow via a direct redirect from the provider authorization page to your without going via TrueLayer.

We recommend that your `return_uri` is a URI that can handle a non-direct return scenario. This ensures that if the `direct_return_uri` isn't registered with the user's chosen provider, the payment can still be authorized through a Truelayer domain.

return_uri.description:
During the authorization flow the end user might be redirected to another page, such as a bank website or TrueLayer's Hosted Payment Page.

This URL determines where the API redirects the user to after they complete the flow on the third-party's website. You must register the `return_uri` in your [settings in Console](/docs/app-settings#allowed-redirect-uris).

scheme_selection.description:
Can your UI render a scheme selection screen?

For payments where you set `scheme_selection` as `user_selected`, your UI must be able to render a screen where the user can select their payments scheme.

This field is required for payments with `user_selected` scheme selection. For other scheme selection types, it's optional.

user_account_selection.description:
Can your UI render a user account selection screen?

If the user has previously consented to saving their bank account details with TrueLayer, they can choose from their saved accounts to speed up following payments.

This field states whether your UI can render a selection screen for these saved accounts. If you omit this, the user isn't presented with this option.

For SEPA payments, the maximum length is **70 characters**. The format must respect the requirements specified [here](https://www.europeanpaymentscouncil.eu/document-library/guidance-documents/sepa-requirements-extended-character-set-unicode-subset-best).

For FPS payments, the maximum length is **140 characters**. The format must respect this regex: `^[a-zA-Z0-9\/\-?:().,+\s#=!"%&*<>;{@\r\n]*$`

For Elixir payments, the maximum length is **70 characters**. The format must respect this regex: `^[a-zA-Z0-9\/\-?:().,'+\s]*$`

For FPS payments, the maximum length is **18 characters**. The format must respect this regex: `^[a-zA-Z0-9\/\-?:().,+\s#=!"%&*<>;{@\r\n]*$`

ensure_minimum_balance_in_minor.description:
The payment is attempted only if the remaining balance in the account is at least this amount.

This should be 'cent' value. eg. 100 = 1GBP.

Payment will only be attempted if the available balance (including any overdrafts) is at least `ensure_minimum_balance_in_minor` + `amount_in_minor`.

for.description:
How long to retry this payment for (between `30m` - `90d`).

This should be the number followed by a unit (e.g `m`, `h` or `d` for minute, hour or day respectively).

type.description:
Smart retry feature increases payment conversion by automatically retrying failed payments based on various criteria.

This feature must be enabled for clients, otherwise the request fails with the 403 Forbidden status code.

for.description:

This should be the number followed by a unit (e.g `m`, `h` or `d` for minute, hour or day respectively).

type.description:
Standard retry feature increases payment conversion by automatically retrying payments that failed due to a provider error.

This feature must be enabled for clients, otherwise the request will fail with a 403 Forbidden status code.

Note: This scheme selection method is only supported by some versions of TrueLayer's mobile SDKs. Only use this option when you're sure that the end user has a version of your app on their device that supports scheme selection, or they won't be able to complete the payment. If you integrate with TrueLayer APIs directly, you must show the user a UI for scheme selection.
SchemeSelectionUserSelected.title: User selected

configuration.description:
Options for the authorization flow configuration of the customized UI.
This should be the same object you use in the start authorization flow request body.

consent.description:
Can the UI capture the user's consent?

This field declares whether the UI supports explicitly capturing and reporting the end user's consent for initiating the payment.
If it is omitted, the providers available may be restricted if explicit consent is required.

form.description:
Can the UI render form inputs for the end user to interact with?

Some providers require additional inputs, such as the remitter name and account details, to be provided before or during payment authorization.
To facilitate this, the API may return a `form` action as part of the authorization flow, prompting the UI to collect the required inputs.

This field declares whether the UI supports the `form` action.
If it is omitted, only providers that do not require additional inputs will be returned. 
If the provider has been preselected and requires additional inputs, this field is considered mandatory.

input_types.description: The types of input that the UI is able to render

provider_selection.description:
Can your UI render a provider selection screen?

In payments where you set provider_selection as user_selected, your UI must be able to render a screen where the user can select their payments provider. This parameter is required for payments with user_selected provider selection. For preselected provider selection, it's optional.

Use the provider_selection.filter parameter at payment creation to determine the list of providers you can choose to display in your UI.

redirect.description:
Can the UI redirect the end user to a third-party page?

For most providers, payment authorization is achieved by redirecting the user to their chosen provider's page, where they can sign in with their credentials and approve the payment.
This field declares whether the UI is able to perform such a redirect.

countries.description: Only providers from the specified countries will be returned.

currencies.description: Only schemes that support at least one of the specified currencies will be returned.

customer_segments.description: Only providers that cater to at least one of the specified customer segments will be returned.

release_channel.description:
Only capabilities that are at least on the specified release channel will be returned.

Note that many European providers are in `public_beta` or `private_beta`.

SearchProviderCapabilities.description: Options for capabilities of the providers.

mandates.description: Only providers with `mandates` capabilities will be returned.

vrp_commercial.description: Only providers with `commercial` capability will be returned.

vrp_sweeping.description: Only providers with `sweeping` capability will be returned.

payments.description: Only providers with `payments` capabilities will be returned.

bank_transfer.description: Only providers with `bank transfer` capability will be returned.

options.description: Exhaustive list of values to select from.

display_text.description: The value to show to the PSU in the UI select dropdown.

id.description: The identifier of the option, this is the value to be submitted back to the API.

search_aliases.description: Alternative search terms for this option.

SettlementStalledAt.description: The date and time at which TrueLayer determined that the payment's settlement was stalled based on the client's chosen delay or the default one.

consent.description:
Can the UI capture the user's consent?

This field declares whether the UI supports the `consent` action, which is used to explicitly capture the end user's consent for initiating the payment.
If it is omitted, the flow will continue without a `consent` action.

provider_selection.description: Can the UI render a provider selection screen?

redirect.description:
Can the UI redirect the end user to a third-party page?

Configuration options are available to constrain if TrueLayer's Hosted
Payment Page should be leveraged.

return_uri.description:
During the authorization flow the end user might be redirected
to another page (e.g. bank website, TrueLayer's Hosted Payment Page).
This URL determines where they will be redirected back once they completed
the flow on the third-party's website.

`return_uri` must be one of the allowed `return_uri`s registered
in TrueLayer's Console.

StartPaymentAuthorizationFlow.description: This object contains a declaration of the client UI's capabilities. The API will adjust the flow depending on this declaration and filter out unsupported providers.

consent.description:
Can your UI capture the user's consent?

This parameter states whether your UI can explicitly capture and report the end user's consent for initiating the payment.

If you omit this, the API may restrict the available providers if explicit consent is required.

action_type.description:
How you will capture consent as part of the authorisation flow:
- `explicit` (default): The authorisation flow returns an explicit `consent` action for you to respond to at an appropriate moment in the flow.
- `adjacent`: You provide the consent information alongside other actions in the flow. This enables the UI to combine capturing consent alongside with other actions, if you indicate consent is gathered when you respond to those actions. Note this is currently only supported on `form` actions.

form.description:
Can your UI render form inputs for the user to interact with?

Some providers require additional inputs, such as the remitter name and account details, to be provided before or during payment authorization. To facilitate this, the API may return a `form` action as part of the authorization flow, which means your UI must be able to collect the required inputs.

This parameter states whether your UI supports the `form` action. If you omit this parameter, the API returns only providers that don't require additional inputs. 

If the provider has been preselected and requires additional inputs, this field is required.

input_types.description: The types of input that your UI can render a form to collect.

provider_selection.description:
Can your UI render a provider selection screen?

In payments where you set provider_selection as user_selected, your UI must be able to render a screen where the user can select their payments provider. This parameter is required for payments with user_selected provider selection. For preselected provider selection, it's optional.

Use the provider_selection.filter parameter at payment creation to determine the list of providers you can choose to display in your UI.

redirect.description:
Can your UI redirect the user to a third-party page?

For most providers, the user authorises the payment after they're redirected to their chosen provider's page. There, they can sign in with their credentials and approve the payment. This parameter states whether your UI can handle such a redirect.

direct_return_uri.description:
Only applicable if you're regulated and have a direct return URI registered with UK providers.

If you're regulated, you can specify a `direct_return_uri` to attempt the authorization flow via a direct redirect from the provider authorization page to your page without going via TrueLayer.

We recommend that your `return_uri` is a URI that can handle a non-direct return scenario. This ensures that if the `direct_return_uri` isn't registered with the user's chosen provider, the payment can still be authorized through a Truelayer domain.

return_uri.description:
During the flow, the end user authorises the payment on a third-party site, such as a bank. The return_uri you set is where the user is redirected to after they complete authorisation on the third-party site.

You must register the `return_uri` in your [settings in Console](/docs/app-settings#allowed-redirect-uris).

scheme_selection.description:
Can your UI render a scheme selection screen?

For payments where you set `scheme_selection` as `user_selected`, your UI must be able to render a screen where the user can select their payments scheme.

This field is required for payments with `user_selected` scheme selection. For other scheme selection types, it's optional.

user_account_selection.description:
Can your UI render a user account selection screen?

If the user has previously consented to saving their bank account details with TrueLayer, they can choose from their saved accounts to speed up following payments.

This field states whether your UI can render a selection screen for these saved accounts. If you omit this, the user isn't presented with this option.

StartPayoutAuthorizationFlow.description: An object representing the request to start a authorization flow for a specific payout

redirect.description:
Can the UI redirect the end user to a third-party page?

For most providers, payment authorization is achieved by redirecting the user to their chosen provider's page, where they can sign in with their credentials and approve the payment.
This field declares whether the UI is able to perform such a redirect.

return_uri.description:
During the authorization flow the end user might be redirected
to another page (e.g. bank website, TrueLayer's Hosted Payment Page).
This URL determines where they will be redirected back once they completed
the flow on the third-party's website.

`return_uri` must be one of the allowed `return_uri`s registered
in TrueLayer's Console.

reference.description:
The reference for the payout, which displays in the beneficiary's bank statement.

For SEPA payments, the maximum length is **140 characters**. The format must respect the requirements specified [here](https://www.europeanpaymentscouncil.eu/document-library/guidance-documents/sepa-requirements-extended-character-set-unicode-subset-best).

For FPS payments, the maximum length is **18 characters**. The format must respect this regex: `^[a-zA-Z0-9\/\-?:().,+\s#=!"%&*<>;{@\r\n]*$`

VRPConstraints.description:
Sets the limits for the payments that can be created by the mandate.

If a payment is attempted that doesn't fit within these constraints it will fail.

These constraints are considered only for VRP mandates (not direct debit).

maximum_individual_amount.description: A 'cent' value representing the maximum amount that can be specified in a payment instruction

periodic_limits.description:
The limits for the payments that can be created by the mandate within a specified time period.

At least one periodic limit must be provided upon mandate creation.

allOf.description: Limit for payments made within a day

Limit for payments made within a fortnight

Only supports `period_alignment` of `consent`.
Limit for payments made within 6 months
Limit for payments made within a month
Limit for payments made within a week
Limit for payments made within a year

periodic_limits.title: Periodic Limits

valid_from.description: Start date time for which the consent remains valid using format `YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ss.sssZ`

valid_to.description: End date time for which the consent remains valid using format `YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ss.sssZ`

maximum_amount.description:
A 'cent' value representing the maximum cumulative amount that all successful payments can claim in the period.

`maximum_amount` must be greater or equal to `maximum_individual_amount` specified on the `constraints` object if `maximum_individual_amount` has been specified.

period_alignment.description:
Specifies whether the period starts on the date of consent creation or lines up with a calendar.

If the `period_alignment` is `calendar`, the limit is pro-rated in the first period to the remaining number of days.

current_amount.description: A 'cent' value representing the current cumulative amount that all successful payments have claimed in the period.

end_date.description: The end date for the current period, and start of the next period

maximum_available_amount.description:
A 'cent' value representing the maximum cumulative amount that all successful payments can claim in the period.

This might be less than the `maximum_amount` requested due to proration on calendar aligned periods.

period_alignment.description:
Specifies whether the period starts on the date of consent creation or lines up with a calendar.

If the `period_alignment` is `calendar`, the limit is pro-rated in the first period to the remaining number of days.

start_date.description: The start date for the current period

WebhookPaymentCreditable.description:
Sent when the payment is ready to be credited to the user, and the services the user has paid for
be granted. Either the payment has settled, or any settlement risk has been accepted.

This webhook is optional, by default it is enabled and it will be sent on payment settlement. [Learn more about the configuration options](/docs/payment-risk-and-credit-notifications), and contact us if you would like this webhook to be disabled or to have a different behavior.

tags.description:
# Payment Mandates

Mandates are a payment source.

A Payment Mandate is a single consent, given by a PSU, to authorise repeated payments on a schedule
or ad-hoc basis. Depending on the use case, the PSU may not be required to authorise payments against
an existing mandate.

The consent given for a mandate will always include the same debtor (or remitter) account. Depending on
the type of Mandate, the creditor (or beneficiary) account may or may not always be the same.

## VRP (Sweeping/Commercial)

Variable Recurring Payments (VRP) are an Open Banking specification allowing a PSU to
authorize repeated payments from their bank account to another account they own.

The PSU only needs to give this consent once. Payments against this consent can then be
initiated by a PSP to move funds between accounts with no further input from the PSU.

When establishing this consent, the PSU will agree to certain parameters that will enforce
limits such as how long the consent will be valid for and what maximum value of transfer will be
allowed over the consent lifetime. Other limits can be set for timeframes within this lifetime.

A new VRP Mandate is created by calling `POST /v3/mandates`, using a bearer token.

OpenBanking VRP Mandates require the end user to go through an authorization flow -
the status of the newly created mandate will therefore be `authorization_required`.
The mandate resource will contain a `mandate_token` that can be safely shared with the UI,
where the authorization flow will be taking place.

The UI can use the `mandate_token` to kick off the **authorization journey**.
Authorizing an OpenBanking mandate usually requires multiple **actions**:
  - collect information from the end user (e.g. select a banking institution);
  - redirect to a bank's website or mobile app;
  - etc.

The UI must specify, using `POST /v3/mandates/authorization_flow`, which **actions** it supports.
Configuration parameters can be specified for each action type - e.g. what `return_uri` to
use for a `redirect` step, if "direct return" is enabled (regulated merchant), etc.

After the call to `POST /v3/mandates/authorization_flow`, the mandate status will transition to `authorizing`.
The UI must now inspect the `authorization_flow.actions.next` field in the mandate resource and submit the required
information via `POST /v3/mandates/authorization_flow/actions`.

The mandate might then transition into `authorized`, or stay in `authorizing` with a different next action.

Should the PSU and/or Provider decide to reject the authorization, the mandate status will
transition to `revoked`.

Payments can only be made against a mandate once it has transitioned to `authorized`. Those payments
will then need to fall within the boundaries set by the consent parameters.

Should the PSU and/or Provider decide to reject the authorization, the mandate status will
transition to `revoked`.
tags.name: Mandates

post.description: Sent to the webhook URI you registered in Console when a mandate becomes authorized, fails, or is revoked.
Sent to the webhook URI you registered in Console when you receive a payment not initiated through TrueLayer to your merchant account.
Sent to the webhook URI you registered in Console when a payment is created from a payment link and when a payment link expires.

Sent to the webhook URI you registered in Console when:
- a payment is authorised.
- a payment is executed.
- a payment fails.
- a payment settles.
- a payment is creditable, according to criteria you specified.
- a payment that has been executed has not settled within a duration you specified.
- an indemnity claim is made against a payment.
- a payment is reversed.
Sent to the webhook URI you registered in Console when a payout succeeds or fails.
Sent to the webhook URI you registered in Console when a refund succeeds or fails.
